Question: What is the planet that almost lies flat on its orbital plane, commonly known as the lazy giant of the solar system?
Parse: The rotation axis of Uranus is almost parallel to the plane of its orbit, with an axial tilt of 97.9 degrees. As a result, it essentially "lies" on its side as it moves around the Sun, earning it the nickname "the lazybones of the solar system." This is a very unique phenomenon, rarely seen among other planets in the solar system. This unique method of rotation gives Uranus a distinct position within the solar system.

Question: The function of a sundial is to.

Also known as a "sundial," it operates on the principle of using the direction of the sun's projection to determine and divide time, typically consisting of a gnomon (indicator) and a dial (a surface marked with scales). The method of using a sundial for timekeeping is a significant invention in the field of astronomical timekeeping, an innovation that has been utilized by humanity for thousands of years.

Question: The cycle of changes in the number of sunspots is approximately ( ).

Question: The only planet in the solar system that rotates in a retrograde direction is ( ).

The direction of rotation of Venus is opposite to its orbit, while all other planets rotate counterclockwise from west to east, Venus rotates clockwise from east to west. This phenomenon of retrograde rotation may have been caused by a collision with another small planet long ago.

Question: Which is the largest planet in the Solar System?

One Jupiter can be equivalent to 318 Earths, hence it is known as the "King of Planets". At the same time, Jupiter is also the largest planet in the solar system, and it has enough gravity to pull space rocks out of their orbit around the Sun.

Question: Which is the fastest-spinning planet in the solar system?

Question: What is the slowest rotating planet in the solar system?

Question: What is the ultimate fate of the Sun?

Question: The definition of an astronomical unit is: ( )
A: The relative angular size of the Sun as seen from Earth is one arcsecond.
B: Distance traveled by light in one year
C: Average distance from Earth to the Sun
D: Time required for light to travel from the sun to the Earth
E: Average distance from Earth to the Moon
Parse: The astronomical unit (AU) is a unit of measurement for distances between celestial bodies in astronomy, denoted as A.U. Its value is taken from the average distance between Earth and the Sun. In 1964, the International Astronomical Union decided to adopt 1 A.U. = 1.496 x 10^8 kilometers, which was used from 1968 until the end of 1983; then in 1978, it was decided to use 1 A.U. = 149,597,870 kilometers starting from 1984. This constant was calculated before the 1960s based on the measured solar parallax; after the 1960s, it was derived from radar astronomical observations, using the speed of light and the light travel time per unit distance, tA. It is generally used to measure distances between celestial bodies within the Solar System.

Question: Which calendar system is used by the Chinese Lunar Calendar?
Parse: The lunar calendar, currently used in China, is a traditional calendar system that combines both the lunar and solar calendars, known as a lunisolar calendar. It is based on the phases of the moon, with each cycle from new moon to full moon considered one month. The year's length is determined by referencing the solar tropical year and includes the addition of twenty-four solar terms and the insertion of leap months to align the average lunar year with the solar year.

According to v=rω， where ω is the same for all points on Earth, achieving a larger linear velocity requires establishing launch sites at locations with the largest radius of rotation. Since Earth rotates around its axis and the rotational radius decreases with increasing latitude, to maximize the linear velocity of rotation at launch, it is ideal to have the largest rotational radius, which is found at the Equator—the location with the lowest latitude. Question: During a total lunar eclipse, when the phenomenon of an occultation of a star by the Moon occurs, the occultation begins with the Moon. ( )
C: Sometimes on the east side, sometimes on the west side.
D: Impossible for the moon to occult a star.
Parse: Starting in the east and ending in the west, this phenomenon occurs because the moon orbits Earth from west to east, while Earth rotates on its axis towards the east. The side of Earth facing away from the Sun is always in darkness. When the moon moves to a position directly behind Earth, Earth blocks the Sun's light, causing a lunar eclipse for those on Earth who can see it. Suppose now a star is to be obscured by the moon; first, it should appear on the eastern side of the moon. As the moon continues its orbit, it will first block the star's light. After a while, the star disappears behind the moon and becomes invisible. Later, it reappears on the western side of the moon.

Question: Neutron stars have a density of up to 10 billion tons per cubic centimeter, mainly consisting of what? ( )

Question: The earliest method for measuring the distance to stars was: ( )
Parse: The triangulation method is a technique used to measure distances by observing the parallax of the same object from different viewpoints. By observing the same object from two points, the lines of sight and the line connecting these two points form an isosceles triangle. The size of the top angle of this triangle can then be used to determine the height of the triangle, which corresponds to the distance between the object and the observer.

Question: The scientist who first discovered the four moons of Jupiter using a telescope is ( ).

To commemorate this significant discovery by Galileo, astronomers named these four satellites the Galilean satellites.

Question: The approximate period of the change in the number of sunspots is ( ).
Parse: Sunspots are a type of solar activity that occurs on the photosphere layer of the Sun, representing the most fundamental and noticeable phenomenon in solar activities. Because their temperature is lower than the surface of the solar photosphere, they appear as dark spots. Sunspots rarely act alone; they often appear in groups. Their activity cycle is 11.2 years. During this time, they can cause damage to Earth's magnetic field and various electronic products and appliances.

Question: Which of the following astronomical phenomena is least likely to occur when observed from Earth?
Parse:
AnalysisA transit refers to the phenomenon where the Sun is obscured by a small, dark celestial body, often a planet within our solar system. It can also be described as an astronomical event where an inner planet passes in front of the Sun's disk. Mercury and Venus orbit within Earth's orbital path and are known as inner planets. If one of these planets happens to pass between Earth and the Sun, observers on Earth will see a black dot moving across the Sun's face for about an hour or more. This phenomenon is called a transit.

AnswerA transit occurs when the Sun is obscured by a small, dark celestial body that must be positioned between the Sun and Earth. Clearly, from Earth, only Mercury and Venus transits can be observed, and the International Space Station, being located between the Sun and Earth, is also visible. Therefore, it is impossible to observe a Mars transit from Earth.

Question: Which crater is the most prominent and has the longest rays when observing the lunar surface with a pair of binoculars during a full moon?

Question: Which constellation is not a zodiac constellation?
Parse: The ecliptic is the path that the Sun appears to take across the celestial sphere, passing through 13 of the 88 constellations in the sky. These 13 constellations are collectively referred to as the zodiac constellations. Dividing the ecliptic into 12 equal segments, each segment is called a "house," forming the "12 houses of the zodiac," and each house is named after one of the zodiacal constellations. This results in 12 zodiacal constellations, each having a corresponding house named after it, collectively known as the "12 signs of the zodiac."

Question: Which of the following constellations is farthest from the Galactic Plane?
Parse: The constellations located furthest from the galactic equator are those containing the north and south galactic poles. The north galactic pole is in the constellation of Coma Berenices, while the south galactic pole is in the constellation of Dorado.

Question: What is the general pattern of moonrise and moonset observed over a long period at the North Pole?
A: Rise and set basically every day.
B: Visible for nearly half a month in succession, then invisible for about half a month.
C: Visible for six months consecutively, then invisible for the next six months.
E: The moon can be seen at a specific time every day.
Parse: This question requires consideration of the Moon's revolution around the Earth. The orbital plane of its revolution passes through the Earth's center and is tilted at a certain angle to the celestial equator, known as the obliquity of the ecliptic. That is, during one lunar month (27.32 days), the Moon spends half the time in the northern celestial hemisphere and half the time in the southern celestial hemisphere. From the North Pole, the entire northern celestial hemisphere is visible. Therefore, from the North Pole, the Moon is continuously visible for about half a month, followed by half a month of continuous invisibility.

Question: What is the name of the space telescope launched in March 2009 specifically for finding exoplanets?

Question: During the total lunar eclipse in December 2011, at which of the following times (Beijing time) could the red moon be observed?
Parse: Astronomers successfully predicted the best lunar eclipse observable in China in nearly a decade, occurring from the evening of December 10, 2011, to the early morning of December 11. This total lunar eclipse began at 19:33 on December 10th, with the initial eclipse, totality, and end of totality taking place at Beijing time 20:45, 22:06, and 22:57, respectively. The period from totality to the end of totality is when the full eclipse can be observed, revealing a red moon. At 22:06, as the moon completely enters the Earth's umbra, it turns entirely red!

Question: When was the 2012 transit of Venus?
Parse: Venus orbits inside the Earth's orbit, and at certain special moments, the Earth, Venus, and the Sun align in a straight line. At these times, from Earth, Venus can be seen as a small black dot moving slowly across the surface of the Sun, a phenomenon known in astronomy as a "transit of Venus." The transit of Venus that occurred on June 6, 2012, was the last one visible until 2117, lasting for up to 6 hours. Most parts of China were in the optimal viewing area.

Question: In which month was the Global Astronomy Month held in 2012?
Parse: April 2010 was designated as the first Global Astronomy Month by the Organization of Astronomers Without Borders. From this, it can be inferred that April 2012 was the third Global Astronomy Month.

Question: The method used to measure the distance of stars that are relatively close to the Sun is ( ).
Parse: Nearby stars are determined using the method of trigonometric parallax, which involves taking photographs of the stars at both ends of Earth's orbit (once every six months) and calculating the distance through the positional differences with distant stars using triangulation. This method can measure up to 500 light-years.

Question: Which of the various legends about December 21, 2012, do you think is correct?
B: "This is the end of the world."
D: The world will experience three consecutive days of darkness before returning to normal.
E: This day holds a special cosmic significance.
Parse: The 2012 Doomsday theory is an apocalyptic belief that claimed the Earth would face catastrophic events on December 21, 2012, or experience phenomena such as "three consecutive days of darkness." Some even specified the exact time of the end of the world as 3:14:35 PM on December 21, 2012. This theory originated from the Mayan calendar, which was believed to conclude on this day. However, according to excavated Mayan texts and the views of mainstream scholars who study Mayan culture, the Mayans did not consider this day as the end of their calendar, nor did they predict it to be the end of the world. The 2012 Doomsday was rated as the worst prediction of 2012 by the American magazine Foreign Policy's website. Therefore, it was just an ordinary day.

Question: What is the correct order of astronomical length units from smallest to largest?
Parse:
In astronomy, the "light-year" is commonly used as a unit of length. It represents the distance that light travels in one year through a vacuum, hence the name "light-year."
1 Astronomical Unit (AU) is approximately 149.6 million kilometers.
1 Light-year equals 9.4653 x 10^12 kilometers.
1 Parsec equals 3.2616 light-years.
Therefore, an Astronomical Unit is smaller than a light-year, and a light-year is smaller than a parsec.

Question: The reason we cannot see the far side of the Moon from Earth is because ( ).
A: The Moon does not rotate on its axis.
B: The Moon's rotation period is the same as its orbital period around the Earth.
D: The moon and the earth revolve around the sun together.
E: The far side of the moon is permanently illuminated by the sun.
Parse: We cannot see the far side of the Moon from Earth because the Moon's rotation period is the same as its orbital period.

Question: Which of the following Messier objects is the farthest from us?
Parse:
The first edition of the "Catalogue of Nebulae and Clusters of Stars," published in 1774, recorded 45 celestial objects, numbered from M1 to M45. By 1780, it was expanded to include M70. The final edition, published the following year, collected a total of 103 celestial objects up to M103. Currently, there are 110 Messier objects, with M104 to M110 being additions made by later astronomers for celestial bodies discovered by Messier and his friend Pierre Méchain that were not included in the original catalogue.
The catalogue records:
M1: 7,200 light-years away from us
M33: 2,500,000 light-years away from us
M42: 1,500 light-years away from us
M45: 410 light-years away from us
M46: 6,000 light-years away from us
Therefore, the correct answer is B.

Question: Which year was the Nobel Prize in Physics not awarded for an astronomical subject?
Parse:
Here is the distribution of the Nobel Prize in Physics for various years:
In 2002, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to American scientist Raymond Davis Jr., Japanese scientist Masatoshi Koshiba and American scientist Riccardo Giacconi for their pioneering contributions to astrophysics, including the detection of cosmic neutrinos and the discovery of cosmic X-ray sources.
In 2006, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to American scientists John Mather and George Smoot for their discovery of the blackbody form and anisotropy of the cosmic microwave background radiation.
In 2009, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to American scientists Charles Kao, Willard Boyle and George Smith for their contributions to the photoelectric effect and semiconductor technology.
In 2011, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to UC Berkeley astrophysicist Saul Perlmutter, American/Australian physicist Brian Schmidt and American scientist Adam Riess for their discovery of the accelerating expansion of the universe.
In 1998, the Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to American scientist Robert Laughlin, German scientist Horst Störmer and American Chinese, Professor of Princeton University, Daniel Chee Tsui, for their discovery of fractional quantum Hall effect in strong magnetic fields.
The prize was not awarded for a topic in astronomy in 2009.

Question: What is the leap month in the lunar calendar?
Parse: A leap month is a type of intercalation method used in the calendar system. It refers to an additional month added during a leap year in the lunisolar calendar. The lunar calendar, which is a type of lunisolar calendar, designates a month without an intercalary month as a leap month, and it is named using the name or ordinal number of the previous month, referred to as "leap such-and-such month."

Question: How many years does it take for the vernal equinox to move 1° along the celestial equator?
Parse:
The vernal equinox moves about 1Â° on the celestial equator in approximately 71.6 years. This is due to the precession of Earth's rotational axis, which causes the vernal equinox to shift westward along the ecliptic at a rate of 50.26 arc seconds per year. Therefore, to calculate the number of years required for a 1Â° shift, we can convert 1Â° into arc seconds (1Â° = 3600 arc seconds) and then divide by the annual shift rate (50.26 arc seconds/year):
50.26/3600 ≈ 71.6 years

Question: Which of the following periods is most suitable for observing Mercury during its greatest western elongation?
Parse:
From Earth's perspective, Mercury always oscillates within a certain range near the Sun. Due to its close proximity, Mercury is often obscured by the Sun's brilliance and is difficult to observe. It is only when Mercury reaches its maximum angular distance from the Sun, known as "greatest elongation," that it becomes relatively easier to spot during dawn or dusk.
Greatest elongations are classified into eastern and western types. When Mercury is at the farthest east of the Sun, it is referred to as an eastern greatest elongation; when it is at the farthest west, it is called a western greatest elongation. Around the time of an eastern greatest elongation, Mercury appears above the western horizon in the evening, and during this period, it is known as an "evening star." Conversely, around a western greatest elongation, Mercury appears low in the eastern sky during dawn, and at this time, it is termed a "morning star."

Question: Astronomers observe simultaneously with an optical telescope and a radio telescope, the diameter of the radio telescope is 500m, and the effective wavelength is 1mm. To achieve the same resolution, what should be the diameter of the optical telescope with an effective wavelength of 550nm?
Parse: Since optical telescopes operate at wavelengths on the order of micrometers, while radio telescopes operate at millimeter scales, there is a difference of 10,000 times between them. Therefore, to achieve the same resolution, the aperture (diameter) of a radio telescope needs to be 10,000 times larger than that of an optical telescope.

Question: On September 14, 2015, astronomers detected gravitational waves for the first time in history: GW150914. This event occurred billions of light-years away from Earth, where two black holes with masses 36 and 29 times that of the sun merged into one ( ) times the mass of the sun black hole.

An amount equivalent to three solar masses was converted into gravitational waves, which radiated outward and swept through the solar system in September last year, providing humanity with the first direct evidence of gravitational waves.

Question: When did the 2017 total solar eclipse occur in local time in the United States?

Question: Which of the following devices or projects is not specifically designed for gravitational wave observation and research?

Question: Which of the following two constellations are not adjacent? ( )

Question: On the Earth's surface, moving 1° in latitude along a meridian corresponds to an actual distance of ( ).
Parse:
Considering Earth as a perfect circle, the left circle represents the change in 1 degree of latitude along the meridian, corresponding to the arc length on the Earth's surface; the right circle represents the change in 1 degree of longitude along the parallel, corresponding to the arc length on the Earth's surface. It is important to note that for the left circle, regardless of the change in longitude, the arc length corresponding to 1 degree of latitude is fixed; for the right circle, at lower latitudes, the arc length corresponding to 1 degree of longitude is larger than at higher latitudes.
Therefore, based on the above analysis, this question should be considered in two parts:
1. Along the meridian, how much distance does a change in 1 degree of latitude represent?
For simplicity in calculation, we consider the length of the equator as the circumference of Earth's circle, with R = 40000 km.
Taking the Northern Hemisphere as an example, where latitude ranges from 0° to 90°， the arc length of the Northern Hemisphere is 40000 / 4 = 10000 km.
Thus, a change in latitude by 1° corresponds to a distance L = 10000 / 90 ≈ 111.11 km.
2. Along the parallel, how much distance does a change in 1 degree of longitude represent?
Although the distance corresponding to a change in 1 degree of longitude varies with different latitudes, using the above calculation method, one only needs to calculate the circumference of the Earth's cross-sectional circle at different latitudes to determine the distance corresponding to a change in 1 degree of longitude at those latitudes.

Question: On August 6, 2012, the Curiosity rover landed on Mars. On October 17, 2015, Curiosity was in the夏普山区， and it was experiencing its second conjunction with which planet since its landing?
Parse: Jupiter is a gas giant with a mass one-thousandth that of the Sun but is 2.5 times the total mass of all the other planets in the Solar System combined. The primary constituent of Jupiter is hydrogen, but helium, making up only one-tenth of the molecular count, accounts for one-quarter of its total mass; it may have a rocky core and heavy elements, but no definitive solid surface can be identified. Due to its rapid rotation, Jupiter appears as an oblate spheroid. Its atmosphere is divided into different latitudinal bands, with turbulence and storms acting at their boundaries. The most notable example is the Great Red Spot, a massive storm first observed through telescopes in the 17th century that has never ceased. Surrounding Jupiter are faint rings and a powerful magnetosphere, including four Galilean satellites discovered in 1610, and by February 2023, Jupiter was known to have 92 moons. Ganymede is the largest of these, with a diameter greater than that of the planet Mercury.

Question: In 2016, astronomers used telescopes and other facilities at the European Southern Observatory to discover a planet within the habitable zone around the nearest star to our solar system.
Parse: Proxima Centauri is the closest star to the solar system, located at a distance of 4.25 light-years. It is also the third star in the triple star system of Alpha Centauri (Rigil Kentaurus), and according to the Bayer designation, it is known as Alpha Centauri C. Together with Alpha Centauri AB, it forms a trinary star system, which serves as the backdrop for the science fiction novel "The Three-Body Problem." It is a red dwarf star with very low brightness, and it was not discovered until 1915 by Robert Innes, then the director of the Union Observatory in Johannesburg, South Africa. A planet of Proxima Centauri, Proxima Centauri b, is located within the habitable zone and may potentially support life. So far, three planets have been discovered around it.

Question: In 2018, how many solar eclipses were visible globally, and how many of these could be observed in China?
Parse:
Xinhua News Agency, Tianjin, August 5th (Reporter Zhou Runjian) - Astronomical experts have revealed that a partial solar eclipse will occur in the evening of the 11th of this month. At that time, the spectacle of the "celestial dog biting the sun" will be visible across the northern part of Asia, including Northern China, much of the Arctic Ocean, the northern parts of North America, and Europe. Additionally, the central and eastern regions of China will also be able to observe a "solar eclipse at sunset."

There are three types of solar eclipses: total solar eclipses, annular solar eclipses, and partial solar eclipses. A partial solar eclipse occurs when, from certain locations on Earth, the Moon blocks a portion of the Sun's light from one side.
Shi Zhicheng, a member of the Chinese Astronomical Society and a director of the Tianjin Astronomical Society, explained that there were three partial solar eclipses worldwide in 2018. The event on the 11th is the third occurrence this year and the only solar eclipse observable in China, under favorable viewing conditions.

Question: The Pauli exclusion principle specifically refers to the fact that any two (fermions) within the same system cannot have identical states of motion.
Parse: The Pauli exclusion principle, also known as the Pauli principle or incompatibility principle, is one of the fundamental laws governing the motion of subatomic particles. It states that in a system composed of fermions, no two or more particles can occupy an identical state. To fully define the state of an electron in an atom requires four quantum numbers; therefore, the Pauli exclusion principle manifests in atoms as follows: no two or more electrons can have the exact same set of four quantum numbers, or in other words, on an atomic orbital defined by the orbital quantum numbers m, l, and n, at most two electrons can be accommodated, with these two electrons having opposite spin directions. This becomes one of the criteria for the periodic arrangement of electrons outside the nucleus, thereby explaining the periodic table of elements.

Question: When Mercury is at perihelion and aphelion, two stationary observers located 100 AU from the Sun observe Mercury's transit across the solar disk. Parse: Mercury's perihelion and aphelion distances are 0.3057 AU and 0.4683 AU, respectively. As a result, Mercury's velocity at these positions is 38.69 km/s and 59.26 km/s, respectively, which is proportional to the angular speed of Mercury as observed. Question: The absolute magnitude of Sirius is 1.5, and the difference in absolute magnitude between the Sun and Sirius is ( ).
Parse: The Sirius system is a binary star system consisting of a main-sequence star with a spectral type of A0 or A1 (Sirius A) and a faint white dwarf with a spectral type of DA2 (Sirius B). The distance between the two varies between 8.2 and 31.5 astronomical units, with a period of 50 years. The Sirius system is only 2.64 parsecs (8.6 light-years) away from Earth, making it one of the closest stellar systems to the Solar System. [15] Moreover, Sirius is gradually approaching the Solar System, and it is estimated that its apparent magnitude will reach a peak of -1.68 in about sixty thousand years. Coincidentally, around the same time, Sirius will become the South Star for Earth in approximately the year 66270 AD. At this time, the distance between Sirius and the South Celestial Pole will decrease to within 1.6 degrees.

Question: In a binary star system, the temperatures of the primary and secondary stars are not much different, and the luminosity of the primary star is about 82 times that of the secondary. The difference in luminosity primarily stems from the difference in the radii of the two stars. Based on this information, estimate the ratio of the radius of the primary to the secondary star to be approximately ( ).
Parse: A binary star system refers to a celestial system composed of two stars that appear very close together in position relative to other stars. A binary star is a pair of stars that orbit around their common center of mass. The term "binary star" can be used interchangeably with "binary star system," but generally, a binary star can be either a physical binary where the stars are physically associated or an optical binary where the stars merely appear close together from Earth's perspective without any physical association.

Question: The first scientist to establish the Hot Big Bang cosmological model was ( ).
Parse: In the late 1940s, the renowned Russian physicist Gamow proposed the Big Bang cosmological model, which posits that the universe originated from a "primeval fireball" explosion 13.7 billion years ago. The Big Bang model is now referred to as the standard theory in cosmology.

Question: In 2022, the Chinese Astronomical Society celebrates its 100th anniversary. The Chinese Astronomical Society was established in ( ) in 1922.
Parse: On October 30, 1922, the Chinese Astronomical Society was established in Beijing, with its offices located at the ancient Beijing Observatory; in 1932, the office was moved to Nanjing, affiliated with the Institute of Astronomy under the Academia Sinica; after 1949, the Chinese Astronomical Society was led by the China Association for Science and Technology and was affiliated with the Purple Mountain Observatory of the Chinese Academy of Sciences.

Question: What is the approximate magnitude difference between two stars with a brightness difference of 10%?
Parse: Two stars with a brightness difference of 10 percent have a magnitude difference of approximately 0.1.

Question: Which of the following lunar seas is located on the far side of the Moon?
Parse: The Moscow Sea (Mare Moscoviens) is a lunar mare located within the Moscow Basin on the far side of the Moon, one of the few maria found there.

Question: What is the scale factor of the universe at a redshift z=1 compared to the present?
Parse: At a redshift z=1, the scale factor of the universe is half of what it is now.

Question: During the best observing conditions, which of the following planets appears brightest when viewed from Earth?
Parse: Venus is the second brightest object in the night sky after the Moon, with a visual magnitude that can reach -4.7, which is sufficient to cast shadows on the ground.

Question: Doing your summer homework makes the days drag on. On which planet, not doing homework would also make the days "drag on"?
Parse: The rotation period of Venus is 243 days.

Question: The displacement of the spectral line Hα in a star's spectrum is recorded as Δλ=0.043×10^{-10} m, and the original wavelength of this line is λ_0=6.563×10^{-7} m. If this observation was made from the equatorial plane of the star, calculate the rotational period of the star. It is known that R_{star} = 8×10^5 km.
Parse:
Doppler of Hα spectral line: $\frac{\Delta\lambda}{\lambda_0}=\frac v{c}$
Therefore: $v=\frac{c\Delta\lambda}{\lambda_0}$
Star is rotating: $\boldsymbol{\upsilon}=\boldsymbol{\omega}\boldsymbol{R}_{\boldsymbol{star}}$

Question: On December 21, 2020, the coordinates of Jupiter were (α，δ) = (20h10m, -20°34'). In which constellation was Saturn located at that time?
Parse: On December 21, 2020, there was a great conjunction, so Saturn and Jupiter were located at the same coordinates in the same constellation. Since Saturn and Jupiter are bodies in the solar system, they must be located in the zodiac constellations on the ecliptic. The vernal equinox is located in Pisces, near its western boundary. Approximating the twelve signs of the zodiac as chunks of about 2 hours in right ascension, we can use the order of the zodiac signs to find that Capricorn spans approximately $\text{RA 20}^h-22^h$, with Saturn and Jupiter being very close to the border between Capricorn and Sagittarius, but Sagittarius is not listed as an answer option.

Question: Jupiter has a mass of 1.90×10^27 kg and a radius of 7.15×10^7 m. Estimate the order of magnitude of the pressure at Jupiter's core in Mbar.
Parse: From hydrostatic equilibrium: $P_c\approx2/3\pi G\rho^2R^2\approx2/3\pi G(M/(4/3\pi R^3))^2R^2=3/(8\pi)GM^2/R^4\approx11\text{ Mbars}$, $1\text{ bar}=10^5\text{ Pa}$.

Question: The combined apparent magnitude of a binary star system in certain specific bands is 5.67. During the secondary minimum, when the second star is completely eclipsed by the first, the apparent magnitude dims to 6.28. What percentage of the total combined flux is produced by the second star?
Parse: The total magnitude, mT = 5.67. During the eclipse, all light comes from the first star (Star A), so mA = 6.28. The magnitude difference can be converted to a flux ratio using the formula mA-mT = $-2.5\log_{10}(\frac{I_A}{I_T})$, and the percentage of flux from Star B is given by $\frac{I_B}{I_T} = 1 - \frac{I_A}{I_T}$.

Question: Who is an academician of the French Academy of Sciences, a founder of celestial mechanics, and one of the creators of the theory of stellar evolution?
Parse: Pierre-Simon, marquis de Laplace (March 23, 1749 - March 5, 1827) was a renowned French astronomer and mathematician, and a member of the French Academy of Sciences. He is considered one of the principal founders of celestial mechanics and one of the creators of the field of astrophysics. Additionally, he is the founder of analytical probability theory, thus it can be said that Laplace was a pioneer in applied mathematics.

Question: Who is credited with the formulation of heliocentrism?
Parse: The heliocentric model was proposed by the Polish astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus.

Question: What is the general tidal cycle observed at the coast on Earth?
Parse: Tidal cycles correspond to the biological periodic activities of tides. On coasts, it is common to observe a tidal fluctuation cycle of 12.4 hours. The periods for spring tides and neap tides are approximately half a month (14.8 days). The corresponding biological activity cycles are referred to as tidal cycles. Especially, the cycles corresponding to the latter are often called lunar cycles or semilunar cycles.

Question: In which year did Galileo discover the Galilean satellites?
Parse: The Galilean satellites of Jupiter are four Jovian moons first discovered in 1610 by the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei using a telescope. They are Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto, ordered by their distance from Jupiter.

Question: What is the largest moon of Neptune, and also one of the coldest objects in the Solar System?
Parse: Triton, Neptune's largest natural satellite and the first to be discovered orbiting the planet, was found by British astronomer William Lassell on October 10, 1846. It is the only large satellite in the solar system with a retrograde orbit, meaning its direction of revolution is opposite to the rotation of its planet. With a diameter of 2706.8 kilometers, Triton ranks as the seventh-largest satellite in the solar system and is the only one of Neptune's moons massive enough to have achieved hydrostatic equilibrium. In terms of mass ratio to its primary planet, it is the second-largest satellite after the Moon in relation to Earth. Due to its retrograde orbit and composition similar to that of Pluto, Triton is believed to be a captured dwarf planet from the Kuiper Belt.

Question: Around which star does Triton revolve?
Parse: Neptune (English: Neptune, astronomical symbol: ♆) is one of the eight major planets in the Solar System and is also the farthest known large planet from the Sun. Neptune has an orbital semi-major axis of 30.07 astronomical units, a revolution period of 164.8 years, a mass of 17.147 Earth masses (third largest, slightly larger than its nearest neighbor Uranus), and a radius of 3.86 Earth radii (fourth largest).

Question: What is the axial tilt of Mars?
Parse: Mars has an axial tilt of 25.19 degrees, similar to that of Earth, which results in it also having four seasons, although the length of each season is about twice as long as on Earth.

Question: In what year did Christiaan Huygens first measure the rotation period of Mars?
Parse: Christian Huygens first measured the rotation period of Mars in 1659, a measurement that differs from modern measurements by less than three minutes.

Question: As of 2022, how many natural satellites has Mars been found to have?
Parse: As of 2022, Mars has two natural satellites, which are Phobos and Deimos.

Question: The distance from Earth to the Moon is about ( ) astronomical units.
Parse: The astronomical unit is a unit of measurement for distances between celestial bodies in astronomy. Represented by A.U., its value is taken as the average distance between Earth and Sun. In 1964, the International Astronomical Union decided to adopt 1 A.U. = 1.496x10^8 kilometers, which was used from 1968 until the end of 1983; then in 1978, it decided to change to 1 A.U. = 149,597,870 kilometers, starting from 1984. This constant was previously calculated from the observed solar parallax before the 1960s; after the 1960s, it was derived from radar astronomical observations based on the speed of light and the unit distance light travel time tA. It is generally used to measure distances between various celestial bodies within the Solar System. [1]

Question: In August 2019, amateur astronomer Gennady Borisov discovered a comet-like object, which was confirmed to be the (number) known object from outside the solar system.
Parse: On August 30, 2019, amateur astronomer Gennady Borisov from the Crimea's MARGO Observatory discovered a comet-like object using his homemade 0.65-meter telescope. After a week of follow-up observations by amateur and professional astronomers worldwide, the Minor Planet Center of the International Astronomical Union (IAU) calculated its initial orbit and found that it was an interstellar object from outside the solar system—the second known cosmic traveler to pass through the solar system.
